comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: What's nice about this photo is that the buckets are not there for the "atmosphere" as they would be today.  They are either for sale or to catch drips from the ceiling and I suspect given their location that it is the latter.  In those days half pints were rather ladylike, not much testosterone on view in that shot!

comment.author: 31536722@N00
comment._content: Beautiful. No ice-cold pints or mobile phone posers in our pubs in those days!

comment.author: 47044499@N03
comment._content: Lovely pub shot. If you ever come across one of what is now called the 'Wicked Swan' in Wexford, I'd love to see it as it was owned by my grandfather and was where my father grew up. It was, I understand, known as Ennis's bar in the very early 20's and probably before then - but I'd love confirmation of this. Patrick James Ennis www.facebook.com/pages/The-Wicked-Swan/157566564296684?v=...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47044499@N03] Nothing turned up in a swift search, but perhaps Ennis's may turn up in a Wexford shot that was focussed on another premises, or on people...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47044499@N03] No problem at all! That's what I'm here for...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/74546365@N07] I'm so sorry, I missed your comment from 4 months ago! I should be drummed out of Library Towers. Are you fairly happy this was taken in Furey's Pub?

comment.author: 88162413@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Not lady like. Bottles of Stout were popular in the 50s/60s, and they were always drank in a half glass.

comment.author: 88162413@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland]  I too believe that this could be Fureys Pub, I wouldn't be 100% sure but there is an Old pub in Moyvalley Co.Kildare called Fureys.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 92860155@N05
comment._content: Yes it is, Fred lived in the station in Moyvalley till he died on 7 July 1977. Grandson

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/92860155@N05] Hi again, Graham. So stupid of me not to connect this Fred with Fred McDonagh in our Enfield photo.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: On the OS 25" map, you can see that Furey's (the building at Moyvalley Bridge) is only a stone's throw from the station.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] You weren't kidding about "a stone's throw"!
